awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Evaluating the Process-Structure-Property Relationships of Carbon Nanotube Forests with In-Situ Synthesis Observation and Dynamic Simulations
awd_abstract_narration:
This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program research project investigates how carbon nanotubes interact with one another during collective growth by using direct observation and complimentary numerical simulation. Nanoscale materials such as carbon nanotubes offer superior mechanical, electrical, and thermal properties relative to many other conventional engineering materials. When vast arrays of carbon nanotubes are synthesized together they form interconnected and self-organized populations known as carbon nanotube forests. The interactions between growing nanotubes lead to the structures bending and kinking which detract from their mechanical properties.  Numerical simulations employing artificial intelligence and machine learning will facilitate the rapid exploration of high-dimensional processing space associated with nanotube formation and will guide the experimental aspects of this project. The results of this work and the understanding of the synthesis process will help control the mechanisms of carbon nanotube interactions during their synthesis, leading to enhanced and engineered carbon nanotube forest properties. Middle school students will be engaged with the research through a one-week summer camp in which hands-on nanoscale materials engineering will be merged with artistic expression through collaboration with the University of Missouri Museum of Art and Archeology. The results of these investigations will enable the use of the art and observation at the nanoscale to engage and inspire grade school children in STEM-based learning in cooperation with the university art museum.

The forces and mechanisms that drive carbon nanotube forest self-assembly are currently poorly understood, in part because in-situ diagnostic techniques with sufficient resolution to interrogate the evolving mechanical interactions are lagging. This project will implement direct visualization of carbon nanotube forest growth and assembly using in-situ synthesis methods within scanning and transmission electron microscopes. A variety of synthesis conditions will be investigated to link the role of important processing factors to the observed behaviors. Transmission electron microscope techniques will facilitate not only time-resolved visual inspection of individual nanotubes and their host catalyst nanoparticles but also compositional analyses at or near atomic resolution. Scanning electron microscope techniques will examine coordinated assembly of carbon nanotubes within the larger population at length scale ranging from tens of nanometers of tens of microns. Experimental observations will be input into a time-resolved finite element simulation to interrogate the forces generated during nanotube forest assembly. After synthesis, the mechanical properties of carbon nanotube forests will be measured using in-situ scanning electron microscope compression and simulated with the finite element model for validation. The validated model will serve as a vehicle for rapid assessment of process-structure-property relationships using an artificial intelligence algorithm to autonomously search for appropriate synthesis conditions that satisfy user-defined forest property sets. A carbon nanotube forest synthesis simulation tool will be made publically available at nanohub.org to facilitate broader impact of the simulations developed in this project.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Carbon nanotubes (CNTs) are carbon molecules with a diameter on the order of 1-40 nanometers and a length of up to centimeters. CNTs have mechanical, thermal, and electrical properties that exceed the state-of-the-art commercial materials. Unfortunately, when CNTs are grown in dense populations known as CNT forests, their ensemble properties are severely diminished. The interactions between neighboring CNTs during their growth act to severely deform and distort the CNTs, diminishing properties. To fully exploit the beneficial properties of CNT populations, methods are needed to understand the interactions between growing CNTs.

This project investigated the dynamic synthesis of dense CNT forests using in-situ scanning electron microscope (SEM) synthesis and complementary simulations. We established a chemical vapor deposition synthesis method within an SEM using heating and biasing substrates. The technique enables direct observation of CNT forest synthesis in real time. We observed the entire life cycle of CNT forests from CNT nucleation from catalyst nanoparticles to self-termination. From our studies, we observed that the CNT forest growth rate decays with time. We also directly observed the detachment of CNTs from their growth substrate due to mechanical forces between growing CNTs. CNTs detach from their host catalyst nanoparticles or at the nanoparticle-substrate interface. These observation indicate different mechanisms may trigger CNT detachment. Because of CNT detachment, the areal density of CNTs within the forest decreased with time, as measured with image analysis tools. We also measured the electrical resistance across the base of a growing CNT forest, which provides a direct indication of CNT density decay with time. Further development of this technique will be used to quantify CNT forest density.

A finite element simulation tool was developed to model both the synthesis of CNT forests and their response to mechanical and electrical stimuli. Using combined in-situ SEM observations and simulation, we estimate that a tensile load on the order of 10 nN is required to detach CNTs. We also observe that rapidly growing CNTs are responsible for providing the forces required to detach CNTs. The electrical resistance of growing CNT forests was simulated in a configuration that matched physical experiments. The simulated resistance of growing CNT forests is quite similar to that observed experimentally, providing confidence in the simulation results.

The project provided funding to support two doctoral mechanical engineering students and two undergraduate students. These students participated in outreach activities including interactive MU Engineering Week Open House demonstrations of optical and electron microscopes to motivate STEM education. These activities reached an estimated 2,000 5-12 grade students over the course of the project. The research project was also the foundation for a writing project assigned to the PI's MAE 2200 (Engineering Materials) course. The learning objective of the project was to provide a hands-on tool to understand the process-structure-property relationships of materials. From these classes, eight students enrolled in undergraduate research with the PI. Of these, four have enrolled in graduate school or applied to graduate school to work with the PI. To faciliate broad collaboraiton, the CNT forest simulation developed in this award is posted as open-source code at GitHub. In these ways, the project had direct broader impacts to the PI, the students in the PI's classes, and the surrounding communities.

 


Last Modified: 10/28/2023
Modified by: Matthew R Maschmann
